results.title: How the West was won
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Cinerama, Bernard Smith, Alfred Newman, Henry Hathaway and John Ford
results.brief_description: This is the epic story of a family that moves West, and the many dangers encountered on the way. The story follows the Prescott family in their quest for land, gold, and glory - in their journey from the Erie Canal in the East to the magic of California in the West. Stars John Wayne, Debbie Reynolds, Carroll Baker and Lee J. Cobb.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Cinerama, Bernard Smith, Alfred Newman, Henry Hathaway and John Ford

results.title: How the west was lost: the story of the 1946 Aboriginal pastoral workers' strike
results.creator_credit: David Noakes, Heather Williams, Market Street Films and Friends Film Productions
results.brief_description: The story of the 1946 Aboriginal Pastoral Workers’ Strike. Eight hundred aboriginal station workers walked off sheep stations in the north west of Western Australia, marking the beginning of a strike which lasted more than three years. The strike was more than a demand for better wages and conditions, it was a struggle for basic human rights.

results.title: How the myth was made
results.creator_credit: George C. Stoney, Films Incorporated and James B. Brown
results.brief_description: Reconstructs the filming of Robert Flaherty’s film “Man of Aran”. Includes interviews with participants in the original project and raises questions about some scenes in the original film, which were of long discontinued activities re-enacted for the 1934 film. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: How the motor car works
results.brief_description: This series explains the mechanics of the motor car, a machine that has changed the world profoundly, influencing economic and social development. Areas covered on the tape include the petrol engine, the carburettor, engine lubrication and the diesel engine.

results.title: How the kiwi lost his wings
results.brief_description: Animated adaptation of a Maori legend about the kiwi and other birds of the forest. Story by Alwyn Owen and told by Peter Gwynne. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: How the historian proves a hypothesis
results.creator_credit: Social Studies Curriculum Development Center, Carnegie Institute of Technology
results.brief_description: Uses a ninth-grade class to demonstrate the inquiry method of teaching students how the historian proves a hypothesis in the study of history. From the “Inductive Teaching of the Historian’s Method of Inquiry series, No. 2”.
